question: Wait, wait! Everybody, wait! There are plenty of planes coming. Now everybody have patience. Everything will be all right.
answer: You have nothing to worry about. Leave everything to my brother.

question: Get me Shanghai. Hello? Hello? Colonel, I need more planes. I've still about twenty people to get out. Where are those planes you promised us? They better get here soon or I can't be responsible
answer: Bob! I think I hear motors! Yes.

question: Just as you say!
answer: The power house - they've blown it up! The planes can't land without lights.

question: All right, go ahead!
answer: Right, Bob.

question: Hello, Fenner. You never mind me. Get this gadget off the ground.
answer: Bob, these are all that are left. Look out, Bob!

question: Get down on the floor, everybody. Go ahead, Fenner!
answer: Fenner, let's go! Whew! That was close.

question: Where did you come from?
answer: I'm Alexander P. Lovett, sir.

question: Why aren't you registered through our office? Where were you hiding?
answer: Hiding? Oh, no. Hunting - I was in the interior - hunting fossils. This morning I looked up suddenly

question: I beg your pardon, brother. What did you say you were hunting?
answer: Fossils.

question: Fossils, huh?
answer: I'm a paleontologist. A paleontologist.

question: Oh, I see.
answer: I have here a discovery that will startle the world. It's the vertebrae from the lumbar of a Megatherium, found in Asia.

question: Well, what do you know about that!
answer: Found in Asia!

question: Uh-huh.
answer: When I get home I shall probably be knighted for it.

question: Knighted! You don't say. Do you mind if I take a look at it? Sorry.
answer: This is the only thing I was able to save when those heathens surrounded me. You see, from this vertebrae I shall be able to reconstruct the entire skeleton.

question: Wait a minute, you expect to be knighted for finding that soupbone?
answer: It was the vertebrae of a Megatherium - found in Asia.

question: Yeah, I remember. You said that before.
answer: Sir Henry Derwent was knighted, and he never got beyond the mesozoic era.

question: Ah, poor fellow.
answer: Yes, it just shows Don't call me brother.

question: Just what I needed too. Just this once, Bob. I feel like celebrating. Just think of it, Bob - a cruiser sent to Shanghai just to take you back to England. You know what it means. How I'm going to bask in reflected glory!
answer: Don't talk nonsense. Give me the bottle.

question: That's why they're sending for you, Bob. With all these foreign entanglements, it was bound to happen. They need you. All right, you can laugh if you want to. But who else can they get? Who else is there in all of England half the fighter, half the diplomat, who Yes, Bob.
answer: Did you say we saved ninety white people?

question: Yes.
answer: Hurray for us. Did you say that we left ten thousand natives down there to be annihilated? No, you wouldn't say that. They don't count.

question: You'd better try to get some sleep, Bob.
answer: Just you wait until I'm Foreign Secretary. Can't you just see me, Freshie, with all those other shrewd, little Foreign Secretaries?

question: You'd better not drink any more, Bob. You're not talking sense.
answer: Don't worry, George. Nothing's going to happen. I'll fall right into line. I'll be the good little boy that everybody wants me to be. I'll be the best little Foreign Secretary we ever had, just because I haven't the nerve to be anything else.

question: Do try to sleep, Bob.
answer: Huh? Oh, sure, Freshie. Good thing, sleep. Did you ever notice the sunrise in China, George? Ah, you should. It's beautiful.

question: Good morning, Lovey.
answer: I beg your pardon.

question: I say, good morning, Lovey.
answer: Good morning

question: Eh?
answer: I didn't care for 'sister' last night, and I don't like 'Lovey' this morning. My name is Lovett - Alexander, P.

question: I see.
answer: I see.

question: Well, it's a good morning, anyway.
answer: I'm never conversational before I coffee.

question: Wait a minute. Is it a good morning? Say, we're supposed to be travelling east, aren't we?
answer: Why, of course. Yes.

question: Well, it looks to me as if we're travelling west.
answer: That's ridiculous.

question: Is it?
answer: It certainly is.

question: Look here
answer: Any child knows how to tell direction. Any child. I don't care where the child is - in the air, on the earth, or in the sea. If you face the rising sun, your right hand is the north, and your left hand is the south

question: I always get it twisted because I'm left-handed.
answer: Oh, really?

question: Yes.
answer: Well, you just reverse it. Your left hand is

question: Uh-huh. All I know is - the sun rises in the east, and we're going away from it.
answer: Now you're irritating and absurd! I tell you, we're going west, and Shanghai is east of here!

question: Good.
answer: What if he refuses?

question: We'll smash his face in. That's what we'll do.
answer: Brilliant! I guess we're in for it.

question: In for what?
answer: I don't know. He must have had some purpose in taking the plane away from Fenner.

question: You mean to tell me you're not going to do anything until we land?
answer: What do you suggest?

question: Why, you - you Look here - he may dash us to pieces!
answer: It might afford you a great deal of relief.

question: It might afford you a great deal of relief.
answer: What are these people?

question: I don't know. I can't get the dialect.
answer: Look - they're loading up with gasoline.

question: George - everybody - better get back towards the tail! He may nose her over. Into the corner, quick! George - cushions, blankets! Everybody all right?
answer: What is it? Has he fainted?

question: It looks like it. He's dead.
answer: Dead?

question: It must have happened the moment he hit the ground.
answer: What is it?

question: See that spot?
answer: Yes.

question: It's magic! Mr. Barnard, I do not like this place. I definitely do not like this place.
answer: Will you stop squawking!

question: Look at me. Look at what they gave me to wear.
answer: You never looked better in your life. As soon as our clothes are cleaned, they're going to give them back to us, Lovey. Something tells me this means food. Come on!

question: I just feel as though I'm being made ready for the executioner. That's what they do with cattle just before the slaughter. Fatten them.
answer: Uh-huh. You're a scream, Lovey.

question: Is there something I can do for you?
answer: What do you want?

question: I've offered you some warm broth. I thought perhaps-
answer: You get out of here! If any of you men think you can come busting in here-

question: Please calm yourself. You'll soon be well if you do. I'm sorry, but we have no doctors here. Please let me help you.
answer: Sure, you can help me! You can help me jump over that cliff! I've been looking and looking at the bottom of that mountain, but I haven't got the nerve to jump!

question: It's always been a source of deep regret, but the mountains surrounding us have made reception almost impossible.
answer: In that event, we better make arrangements to get some porters immediately. Some means to get us back to civilization.

question: Are you so certain you are away from it?
answer: As far away as I ever want to be.

question: Oh, dear.
answer: Of course, the porters will be very well paid - that is, within reason.

question: I'm afraid that wouldn't help. You see, we have no porters here.
answer: No porters here!!

question: No.
answer: What about those men we met this morning?

question: Yes. Those are our own people. They never venture beyond the point where you were met this morning. It is much too hazardous.
answer: How do you account for all this? Who brought it in?

question: Thinking? What about some double solitaire?
answer: As a matter of fact, I'm very good at double solitaire.

question: No kidding?
answer: Yes.

question: Hello, George.
answer: Thanks.

question: We've had plenty of it the last few days.
answer: It's far from over, from what I can see. This place gives me the creeps, hidden away like this - no contact with civilization. Bob, you don't seem concerned at all.

question: Oh, I'm feeling far too peaceful to be concerned about anything.
answer: You talk as though you intend on staying. What are you talking about? You're a strange bird. No wonder Gainsford calls you the man who always wanted to see what was on the other side of the hill.

question: Don't you ever want to see what's on the other side of the hill?
answer: What could there be except just another hill? In any event, I'm not curious. At the moment, it seems to me we should be concerned about getting home. I'd give anything to be in London right now.

question: Of course you would. If ever we get out of this place, the thing for you to do is to take that job with Helen's father.
answer: What do you mean if we should get out?

question: Well - I mean
answer: What's on your mind, Bob? You talk as though we're going to have trouble getting out of here.

question: George, I've been putting things together. Do you notice the resemblance between those natives and the pilot? And why did those clothes materialize so conveniently when they met us at the plane? Chang himself just said that they never venture beyond that point. What brought them there? Unless it was to meet us? Uh-huh.
answer: There must be some connection between the plane and this place. They must have deliberately brought us here. Why, Bob? What reason could they have for doing a thing like that?

question: That's what's on the other side of the hill.
answer: It's three thousand feet, practically straight down to the floor of the valley. The Valley of the Blue Moon, as we call it. There are over two thousand people in the Valley besides those here in Shangri-La.

question: Who and what is Shangri-La? You?
answer: Goodness, no! So there are others? Oh, yes.

question: Who, for instance?
answer: In time you will meet them all.

question: By the way, what religion do you follow here?
answer: We follow many.

question: That's intelligent.
answer: We find, in the Valley, it makes for better happiness among the natives. We rule with moderate strictness and in return we are satisfied with moderate obedience. As a result, our people are moderately honest and moderately chaste and somewhat more than moderately happy.

question: How about law and order? You have no soldiers or police?
answer: Oh, good heavens, no!

question: How do you deal with incorrigibles? Criminals?
answer: Why, we have no crime here. What makes a criminal? Lack, usually. Avariciousness, envy, the desire to possess something owned by another. There can be no crime where there is a sufficiency of everything.

question: You have no disputes over women?
answer: Only very rarely. You see, it would not be considered good manners to take a woman that another man wanted.

question: Suppose somebody wanted her so badly that he didn't give a hang if it was good manners or not? That's very convenient. I think I'd like that.
answer: You'd be surprised, my dear Conway, how a little courtesy all around helps to smooth out the most complicated problems. At some time in the future you will have the pleasure of meeting her.

question: Some man had better get ready to be very courteous to me. But Mr. Chang, all these things - books, instruments, sculpture - do you mean to say they were all brought in over those mountains by porters?
answer: They were.

question: Well, it must have taken
answer: Centuries.

question: Centuries! Where did you get the money to pay for all those treasures?
answer: Of course we have no money as you know it. We do not buy or sell or seek personal fortunes because, well, because there is no uncertain future here for which to accumulate it.

question: That would suit me perfectly. I'm always broke. How did you pay for them?
answer: Our Valley is very rich in a metal called gold, which fortunately for us is valued very highly in the outside world. So we merely . . .

question: buy and sell?
answer: Buy and - sell? No, no, pardon me, exchange That, my dear Conway, is the story of a remarkable man.

question: Who?
answer: A Belgian priest by the name of Father Perrault, the first European to find this place, and a very great man indeed. He is responsible for everything you see here. He built Shangri-La, taught our natives, and began our collection of art. In fact, Shangri-La is Father Perrault.

question: When was all this?
answer: Oh, let me see - way back in 1713, I think it was, that Father Perrault stumbled into the Valley, half frozen to death. It was typical of the man that, one leg being frozen, and of course there being no doctors here, he amputated the leg himself. Yes. Oddly enough, later, when he had learned to understand their language, the natives told him he could have saved his leg. It would have healed without amputation.

question: Well, they didn't actually mean that.
answer: Yes, yes. They were very sincere about it too. You see, a perfect body in perfect health is the rule here. They've never known anything different. So what was true for them they thought would naturally be true for anyone else living here.

question: Well, is it?
answer: Rather astonishingly so, yes. And particularly so in the case of Father Perrault himself. Do you know when he and the natives were finished building Shangri-La, he was 108 years old and still very active, in spite of only having one leg?

question: 108 and still active?
answer: You're startled?

question: Oh, no. Just a little bowled over, that's all.
answer: Forgive me. I should have told you it is quite common here to live to a very ripe old age. Climate, diet, mountain water, you might say. But we like to believe it is the absence of struggle in the way we live. In your countries, on the other hand, how often do you hear the expression, "He worried himself to death?" or, "This thing or that killed him?"

question: Very often.
answer: And very true. Your lives are therefore, as a rule, shorter, not so much by natural death as by indirect suicide. Why, Mr. Conway, you surprise me!

question: I surprise you? Now that's news.
answer: I mean, your amazement. I could have understood it in any of your companions, but you - who have dreamed and written so much about better worlds. Or is it that you fail to recognize one of your own dreams when you see it?

question: Mr. Chang, if you don't mind, I think I'll go on being amazed - in moderation, of course.
answer: Honey, it's terrific! Terrific! I just saw something that will make your hair stand on end. You see those hills over there? Gold! Gold! Popping right out of them! Tons of it! Aw say, honey, you aren't feeling well, are you? Look, don't pay too much attention to what those doctors tell you. I've seen an awful lot of people fool them, and I've got a hunch that this place is going to be good for you. Honest, I have.

question: Oh, you speak English, do you? No, thanks. Not just now.
answer: Bah! Fossils! Why? What for? Running around digging up a lot of old bones! You didn't dig yourself out of one of those holes by any chance, did you?

question: Well - I heard that if you want a man's wife, she's yours, if he's got any manners.
answer: Nothing about the porters yet?

question: Porters?
answer: Good heavens, Bob, we've been here two weeks and we haven't found out a thing.

question: Well, we haven't been murdered in our beds yet, George, have we?
answer: I'm afraid the porters are just a myth.

question: And say, honey, you look a million per cent better. Wholesome, kind of - and clean. You take a tip from me, and don't you ever put that stuff on your face again. Why, it's like hiding behind a mask.
answer: Ha, ha - who are you to be talking about a mask? What do you mean? You've been wearing a mask ever since we met you.

question: Have I?
answer: It's very strange, you know. You've never told us anything about yourself. Who are you, anyway? Why don't you take your mask off for once! Certainly not.

question: Believe me, it's no fun. When you fellas picked me up at Baskul, they'd been on my tail for a year. Uh-huh. Bryant's Utilities - that's me.
answer: I knew it. I knew I had a reason for hating you! Sir, you're a thief.

question: I have 500 shares of Bryant Utilities that I bought with money that I saved for 20 years teaching school, and now I couldn't sell it for postage stamps.
answer: That's too bad. I got a half million shares. My whole foundation! And now look at me!

question: A colossal nerve you have sitting there and talking about it so calmly - you, the swindler of thousands of people
answer: You know, that's what makes the whole thing so funny. A guy like me starts out in life as a plumber - an ordinary, everyday, slew-footed plumber - and by the use of a little brains, mind you, he builds up a gigantic institution, employs thousands of people, becomes a great civic leader. And then the crash comes - and overnight he's the biggest crook the country ever had.

question: What makes you think we're ever going to get back? You may not know it, but you're all prisoners here. We were deliberately kidnapped and brought here - and nobody knows why Well, I'm not content to be a prisoner. I'm going to find out when we're going to get out of this place. Chang! Chang!
answer: George, what do you think you're doing?

question: Let me go, Bob!
answer: George, come back!

question: Chang! Chang! Chang! Come here, you! Come here!
answer: George, you idiot!

question: One moment. You say the High Lama is the only one who can give us any information?
answer: The only one.

question: And he can arrange for the porters to take us back?
answer: The High Lama arranges everything, Mr. Conway.

question: Well, then he's the man I want to see. Better wait here until I get back. We'll soon know where we stand.
answer: Please come in. Sit here, near me. I am an old man and can do no one any harm.

question: Are you the High Lama?
answer: Yes. I trust you have been comfortable at Shangri-La, since your arrival.

question: Personally, I've enjoyed your community very much. But my friends do not care for this mystery. They are determined to leave as soon as
answer: What is it, my son?

question: You're the man Chang told me about! You're the first - who - two hundred years ago
answer: Sit down, my son. Oh, not of Conway the empire-builder and public hero. I wanted to meet the Conway who in one of his books, said, "There are moments in every man's life when he glimpses the eternal." That Conway seemed to belong here. In fact, it was suggested that someone be sent to bring him here.

question: That I be brought here? Who had that brilliant idea?
answer: Sondra Bizet. Yes. She has read your books and has a profound admiration for you, as have we all.

question: Of course I have suspected that our being here is no accident. Furthermore, I have a feeling that we're never supposed to leave. But that, for the moment, doesn't concern me greatly. I'll meet that when it comes. What particularly interests me at present is, why was I brought here? What possible use can I be to an already thriving community?
answer: We need men like you here, to be sure that our community will continue to thrive. In return for which, Shangri-La has much to give you. You are still, by the world's standards, a youngish man. Yet in the normal course of existence, you can expect twenty or thirty years of gradually diminishing activity. Here, however, in Shangri-La, by our standards your life has just begun, and may go on and on.

question: But to be candid, Father, a prolonged future doesn't excite me. It would have to have a point. I've sometimes doubted whether life itself has any. And if that is so, then long life must be even more pointless. No, I'd need a much more definite reason for going on and on.
answer: We have reason. It is the entire meaning and purpose of Shangri-La. It came to me in a vision, long, long, ago. I saw all the nations strengthening, not in wisdom, but in the vulgar passions and the will to destroy. I saw their machine power multiply until a single weaponed man might match a whole army. I foresaw a time when man, exulting in the technique of murder, would rage so hotly over the world that every book, every treasure, would be doomed to destruction. This vision was so vivid and so moving that I determined to gather together all the things of beauty and culture that I could and preserve them here against the doom toward which the world is rushing. You must come again, my son. Good night.

question: George. George - do you mind? I'm sorry, but I can't talk about it tonight. Do you mind?
answer: This is Mr. Conway, children.

question: How do you do?
answer: All right, children. We will now sing Do you mind?

question: Not at all.
answer: Thank you.

question: All right, children. Now teacher is going to be very busy this afternoon, so school's dismissed! Oh, please. I hope you're not going to run away this time. I hope you'll forgive me for
answer: Oh, you mean my pigeons. You see, this is how we tie them on. And by varying the size of the flutes, I can get any notes I wish. The wind does the rest. Here's a little fellow who lost his! Yes. Hold this pigeon.

question: You suggested my being brought here, didn't you? What gave you the idea I'd fit in?
answer: That was easy. I read your books.

question: Oh, you've read my books. You do more things! What have my books got to do with it?
answer: I saw a man whose life was empty.

question: A man whose life was empty!
answer: Oh, I know. It was full of this and full of that. But you were accomplishing nothing. You were going nowhere, and you knew it. As a matter of fact, all I saw was a little boy whistling in the dark.

question: A little boy whistling in the dark!? Do you realize that there is a British cruiser waiting at Shanghai, smoke pouring out of its funnels, tugging at its moorings, waiting to take Mr. Conway back to London? Do you know that at this minute there are headlines shrieking all over the world the news that Conway is missing? Does that look like a man whose life is empty?
answer: I really only brought you here to show you my pigeons!

question: Don't worry about the pigeons. From now on, you can put flutes on my tail and bells on my feet! There are so many questions I'd like to ask you, I hardly know where to begin.
answer: I'll help you. To begin with, you'd like to know what I'm doing here. Whether I was born here.

question: Thank you.
answer: Well, I was almost born here. It took place in that wild country beyond the pass. My father and mother were in a party of explorers who got lost and wandered around for a year. When Chang found us, only Father and I were alive. But he was too weak to climb the pass. He died on the way. I was brought up here by Father Perrault himself.

question: Father Perrault! I envy you. I talked to him last night.
answer: Yes, I know.

question: Father Perrault. Of course I can't quite get used to this age thing. Oh, you're going to make life very simple.
answer: What is?

question: All of it. Father Perrault and his magnificent history. This place, hidden away from the rest of the world, with its glorious concepts, and now you come along and confuse me entirely.
answer: I'm sorry. I thought I was to be the light. But why do I confuse you? Am I so strange?

question: On the contrary, you're not strange. And that in itself is confusing. I have the same idea about Shangri-La. The sense that I've been here before, that I belong here.
answer: I'm so glad.

question: I can't quite explain it, but everything is somehow familiar. The very air that I breathe. The Lamasery, with its feet rooted in the good earth of this fertile valley, while its head explores the eternal. All the beautiful things I see, these cherry blossoms, you - all somehow familiar.
answer: Perhaps because you've always been a part of Shangri-La without knowing it.

question: I wonder.
answer: I'm sure of it. Just as I'm sure there's a wish for Shangri-La in everyone's heart. I have never seen the outside world. But I understand there are millions and millions of people who are supposed to be mean and greedy. Yet I just know that secretly they are all hoping to find a garden spot where there is peace and security, where there's beauty and comfort, where they wouldn't have to be mean and greedy. Oh, I just wish the whole world might come to this valley.

question: I don't know why I associate with you, Mr. Barnard - or Mr. Chalmers Bryant - or Mr. Embezzler - or whatever your name may be.
answer: Just call me Barney.

question: Barney? Why should I? Never! We have nothing in common. Hmmpf, Barney! What effrontery!
answer: Okay, Lovey.

question: And this trip to the valley. I can't imagine why I'd allow you to drag me down here. Why, we don't know anything about these people. We're not even armed!
answer: They're very nice people - except that they've got horns.

question: Horns? What kind of horns?
answer: Here, here! Come on. They won't hurt you. Okay, honey, all I want is a glass of wine! Thanks very much. This is fine. This is swell. No, just a drink. I've been walking and I'm a little thirsty, you see? That's all right. I don't just happen to be very hungry. Say look, all I asked for was a glass of water. Look here, I've got to have some help with this.

question: Mr. Barnard?
answer: Hey Lovey, come here! Lovey, I asked for a glass of wine and look what I got. Come on, sit down.

question: So that's where you are. I might of known it. No wonder you couldn't hear me.
answer: You were asked to have a glass of wine. Sit down!

question: And be poisoned out here in the open?
answer: Certainly not!

question: I never drink wine in the daytime. then the bears came right into the bedroom and the little baby bear said, "Oh, somebody's been sleeping in my bed." And then the mama bear said, "Oh dear, somebody's been sleeping in my bed!" And then the big papa bear, he roared, "And somebody's been sleeping in my bed!" Well, you have to admit the poor little bears were in a quandary!
answer: I'm going to sleep in my bed. Come on, Lovey! Come on, Lovey.

question: Why? Why 'come on' all the time? What's the matter? Are you going to be a fuss budget all your life? Here, drink it up! Aren't you having any fun? Where was I?
answer: In a quandary.

question: Bump?
answer: When the plane lands at Shangri-La and wakes us all up. Ouch! You know, sometimes I think that it's the other that's the dream. The outside world. Have you never wanted to go there?

question: Goodness, no. From what you tell me about it, it certainly doesn't sound very attractive.
answer: It's not so bad, really. Some phases are a little sordid, of course. That's only to be expected.

question: Why?
answer: Oh, the usual reasons. A world full of people struggling for existence.

question: Struggling, why?
answer: Well, everybody naturally wants to make a place for himself, accumulate a nest egg, and so on.

question: Why?
answer: You know, if you keep on asking that, we're not going to get anywhere. And don't ask me why.

question: I was just going to.
answer: It's the most annoying word in the English language. Did you ever hear a child torture his parent with it? Because mother read it in a book somewhere, and if mother's little darling doesn't take her fingers out of the salad bowl this instant, mother's going to wring her little neck. I'd love it!

question: Why?
answer: Forgiven.

question: Amazing, Mr. Chang. This place is amazing! And that marble quarry in the valley is simply magnificent. Oh, I've looked around. I've seen everything. Your woodworkers and your cloth-weavers - they all seem so very, very happy.
answer: Yes.

question: You may not know it, Mr. Chang, but right here you have Utopia.
answer: You've very kind Mr. Lovett.

question: I don't mean it in that sense. I only give credit where credit is due.
answer: Oh, I'm so glad.

question: Simply preposterous. Do you know what I did last night? Last night, Mr. Chang, I held a sort of a self-inventory. I said to myself last night, Mr. Chang, I said, "Lovey"
answer: Why, no.

question: "Ungrateful fool . . . !" Those were my very words to myself last night. "Here are these people in Shangri-La doing everything in their power to make our stay comfortable and happy and I haven't done one single thing to show my appreciation."
answer: Now, what would you like to do?

question: Well, Mr. Chang, I thought, with your permission of course, and while I'm waiting for these porters, I would like to organize classes for those children in the valley and teach them something practical and something useful. Geology.
answer: Splendid!

question: Isn't it? Isn't it! You know I was a professor for twenty years? - and a very good one.
answer: I'm sure you were. When would you like to start?

question: Oh, immediately. Oh, thank you. Thank you!
answer: Thank you.

question: Charming, isn't she?
answer: Yes, charming.

question: Your brother seems quite fascinated by her.
answer: Why not? She's an attractive young woman.

question: Young? She arrived here in 1888. She was 20 at the time. She was on her way to join her betrothed - when her carriers lost their way in the mountains. The whole party would have perished but for meeting some of our people. Not for years. Shangri-La will keep her youthful indefinitely.
answer: Suppose she should leave it?

question: Leave Shangri-La! That's not likely. You couldn't drive her out.
answer: No, I mean about her appearance. If she should leave the valley - what would happen?

question: Yes, of course, your brother is a problem. It was to be expected.
answer: I knew you'd understand. That's why I came to you for help.

question: You must not look to me for help. Your brother is no longer my problem. He is now your problem, Conway.
answer: Mine?

question: Because, my son, I am placing in your hands the future and destiny of Shangri-La. I knew my work was done when I first set eyes upon you. I have waited for you, my son, for a long time. I have sat in this room and seen the faces of newcomers. I have looked into their eyes and heard their voices - always in hope that I might find you . My friend, it is not an arduous task that I bequeath, for our order knows only silken bonds. To be gentle and patient, to care for the riches of the mind, to preside in wisdom, while the storm rages without.
answer: Do you think this will come in my time?

question: Oh, that's a cinch. I'll show them how to cast pipes out of clay.
answer: There you are! Barnard, you'd better get your things together. We're leaving.

question: Leaving?
answer: Yes. I've just been talking with the porters. They're going to take us. We've got clothing, food, everything. Come on!

question: When are you going to start?
answer: Right this very minute! The porters are waiting for us on the plateau. And that Chinaman thought he could stop me. Come along.

question: I think I'll stick around. I'll leave with the porters on their next trip.
answer: You mean you don't want to go?

question: Well - I'm
answer: I see. You're afraid of going to jail, eh?

question: Well, no. You see, I got this plumbing business
answer: All right! If you insist on being an idiot, I'm not going to waste time coaxing you.

question: Oh, no - you don't want to go yet, honey. Sure - sure. Don't you worry. I'll take care of you.
answer: All right, suit yourself. But just remember you had your chance. How about you? Do you want to go?

question: Well, you can stop worrying about everything now, Bob. I've made arrangements to leave. If you'll let me close that window, I can talk to you. That noise is driving me crazy. I said we're getting out of here. Back to civilization. I made a deal with the porters. They brought in a load of books or something, and they're leaving tomorrow at dawn. They're waiting for us five miles outside the valley. Come on, get your things together. Where's your top coat?
answer: You can't leave, George.

question: Why not? What's going to stop me? I don't know what you're talking about. You're carrying around a secret that seems to be eating you up. If you'll only tell me about it.
answer: I will, George. I want to tell you. I'll burst with it if I don't. It's weird and fantastical and sometimes unbelievable, but so beautiful! . . . And that's the whole story, George. He died as peacefully as the passing of a cloud's shadow. His last words to me were, "I place in your hands, my son, the future and destiny of Shangri-La." Now you know why I can't leave. So you think I'm mad?

question: What else can I think after a tale like that? Good heavens, Bob, things like that don't happen today. We're living in the twentieth century.
answer: So you think it's all nonsense, huh?

question: I think you've been hypnotized by a lot of loose-brained fanatics. Why, I wouldn't believe it if I heard it in an English monastery. Why should I swallow it here in Tibet? How do you know the things they told you are true? Did they show you any proof?
answer: I don't need any proof. Is that all my story meant to you?

question: What else could it mean to me? It's obviously a lot of bunk.
answer: Then you'd better go, George. This is no place for you.

question: It's no place for you, Bob. Think of what's waiting for you. Do you want to stay here until you're half dead? Until your mind starts corroding like the rest of them?
answer: Please, George. I don't want to talk about it anymore.

question: You've got to talk about it. What about me? You said they stole that plane to bring you here. I didn't want to come. You owe me some responsibility.
answer: I'm tired of owing you things. You're free to go. Go ahead. Enough! Never mind the girl!

question: Look here, Bob, Ever since I can remember, you've looked after me. Now I think you're the one that needs looking after. I'm your brother, Bob. If there's something wrong with you, let me help you. Besides, I - I don't feel like making that trip alone, Bob.
answer: George, you couldn't possibly stay here, could you?

question: I'd go mad! Yes, the little Russian girl.
answer: What's she got to do with it?

question: She's going with me.
answer: She came here in 1888!

question: This would be funny - if it wasn't so pathetic. Why, she isn't a day over twenty!
answer: You're wrong, George.

question: But you promised me! You promised to take me with you! It's all your fault! It was all arranged until he spoke to you! Why can't you leave us alone?
answer: Do you mean to tell me you want to leave Shangri-La?

question: I'll die if I have to stay here another minute! I've waited a long time for this chance to go, and you're not going to stop me now. If I have to, I'll go alone. It was I who bribed the porters. If it weren't for me, you'd never get out!
answer: I thought the porters had instructions from the High Lama not to take anyone.

question: The High Lama? Who pays any attention to him? The porters laugh at the High Lama. All they want to know is how much gold he will give them. Well, I gave them more gold. I've been stealing it for a year. I'd do anything to get out of this place. To get away from that High Lama - the one who calls himself Father Perrault! Why, he's been insane for years!
answer: Father Perrault is dead.

question: He's dead? That's fine. You won't see me shedding any tears over him! Old woman? Chang told you that, didn't he?
answer: Yes.

question: Yes, of course. Certainly. Come on!
answer: It won't be long now before we're in London. Can't you just see everyone when we pop out of the blue! We'll have them breathless when they hear our story.

question: What was that?
answer: I was saying

question: What's happened? Where's Bob?
answer: He's going, my child.

question: Going?
answer: But he will return.

question: Cable from Gainsford.
answer: Oh, read it! All right, give it to the press.

question: All of it?
answer: Yes. Might as well - all of it.

question: Yes, sir.
answer: I'll dispatch a convoy to meet him.

question: Conway's gone again! Run out! Listen to this! From Gainsford.
answer: Let me have it.
